subject: Did you attend London Perl Workshop 2019?
header: We have had great workshop last Saturday. Lots of interesting talks to attend. It was pleasure to be part of the show. It also presented the opportunity to meet friends. As you all know, LPW moved to new venue this time, everybody liked the venue.
If you did attend the event then please do share your experience with us.
Enjoy the rest of the week.

entries.title: Perlyglot
entries.author: brock_wilcox
entries.text: Our small team really enjoys organizing the mostly-annual DC-Baltimore Perl Workshop, and we're working on it again for 2020

chapters.title: Perl Weekly Challenge
chapters.header: The Perl Weekly Challenge by Mohammad Anwar will help you step out from your comfort-zone. You can even win the prize money of $50 Amazon voucher by participating in the weekly challenge. The weekly prize is kindly sponsored by Peter Sergeant of PerlCareers.

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 031

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.
entries.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 030

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Please check out the short interview with the "Perl Weekly Challenge - 029" winner Dave Jacoby.
entries.title: Meet The Champion - Dave Jacoby

entries.author: adam_russell
entries.text: Reading Adam's blog always enjoyable, specially the section NOTE in the end.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 030

entries.author: arne_sommer
entries.text: If you want to fall in love with Raku, just read the solution to Christmas day task by Arne. I bet you will not be disappointed.
entries.title: Christmas Twelfth Cometh Perl 6

entries.author: dave_jacoby
entries.text: Dave used just 2 for-loops instead of 3 to solve the number series task with a nice little hack.
entries.title: Blogging Challenge 30

entries.author: e_choroba
entries.text: Checkout the trick used by Choroba in the blog.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 030: Sunday Christmas and Series with sum 12

entries.author: jaldhar_vyas
entries.text: Jaldhar shared really nice tricks with regard to the Christmas day task. "Christmas always falls on December the 25th which is exacly one week before New Years Day of the next year. So if we know the next New Years Day is on a Sunday, we know Christmas is on a Sunday. How do we know which day of the week New Years Day is on? Well, January 1, 2019 was on a Tuesday. January 1, 2020 will be on the next consecutive day of the week i.e. Wednesday. For each subsequent year we increment the day of week by one. The only stumbling block is for leap years which have an extra day. So for the year after a leap year, we have to increment by two."
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 30

entries.author: laurent_rosenfeld
entries.text: Please checkout the Raku magic to solve the Christmas date task. You will be amazed.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 30: Sunday Christmas and Triplets

chapters.title: Perl Tutorial
chapters.header: A section for newbies and for people who need some refreshing of their Perl knowledge. If you have questions or suggestions about the articles, let me know and I'll try to make the necessary changes. The included articles are from the Perl Maven Tutorial and are part of the Perl Maven eBook.

entries.title: Change offers amazing opportunites
entries.author: dean_hamstead
entries.text: The Camelia mascot of the language now known as Raku is a brightly coloured metaphor for the transition from Perl 6 to it's new identity.
